hanzi-su-wiki:
奮

Значения

Проявлять активность

Мнемоника

Поедая на поле 田 зерно, дрофы, крупные 大 птицы 隹, начинают возбуждаться и кричать.

Варианты

奋
purpleculture_pinyin:
fèn
to exert oneself (bound form)
напрягаться (скованная форма)
rtega_mnemonic:
奮奮RS
奋奋		strive, exert effort, arouse, take wing, advance
  • RS. like a (big 大) bird spreading its wings 奞 over the field 田: rise in force and advance
  • ⓢ modf. 奮 → 奋
purpleculture_info:
(Simplified: 奋)
Ideographic: A man 大 working on the farm 田
purpleculture_examples:
奮鬥 [ fèn dòu ]: to strive; to struggle
奮戰 [ fèn zhàn ]: to fight bravely; (fig.) to struggle; to work hard
purpleculture_tree:
• ⿳ Above to middle and below
    • 大 [ dà ] big, great, vast, high, deep
    • 隹 [ zhuī ] short-tailed bird; sparrow

heisig_chinese_memo: The St. Bernard dog likes to exert oneself to release energy and pounces on a turkey in a rice field and stirs up all the other birds around. See them all gobble gobbling in fear?
heisig_constituent: stirred up, large, St. Bernard, turkey, rice field, brains
heisig_story: St. Bernard dog . . . turkey . . . rice field/brains.
Keyword_KANJIDIC_ru: перемешивают до, чувствовать себя бодрыми, процветать
koohiiStory1: The St. Bernard dog pounces on a turkey in a rice field and stirs up all the other birds around. See them all gobble gobbling in fear?
koohiiStory2: Gruesome, but it makes it easy to remember. Here goes: The St. Bernard stirred up a crowd of turkeys and caught one. It bit the head, brains spilling onto the rice field.
jp_example_words:
興奮(こうふん): excitement, stimulation, agitation, arousal
奮闘(ふんとう): hard struggle, strenuous effort
WaniKani_Meaning_Mnemonic: A big turkey in the rice paddy is getting all stirred up. He's kicking up all the rice. Who stirred him up?
WaniKani_Meaning_Info: He is a really big turkey too. Like, 12 feet tall, or something. Don't want to stir up a turkey that's that big.
WaniKani_Reading_Mnemonic: While the turkey is stirred up, it also looks like it's having a lot of fun (ふん).
WaniKani_Reading_Info: Is it laughing? Oh no, this is bad, it's enjoying being stirred up, now we'll never stop it.
Ru_Russian: будоражить, возбуждать (любопытство и т.п.), вызывать к жизни
Ru_Words:
奮うふるう
  • вызывать к жизни, разжигать, призывать на помощь (напр. мужество)
  • to muster (e.g. one's courage); to call forth; to rouse up; to be enlivened; to be invigorated
    • EDICT2
    亢奮こうふん
    興奮こうふん
  • возбуждение
    • warodai
    奮戦ふんせん
  • ожесточённый бой
    • 奮撃ふんげき
  • яростная атака
Ru_Radicals: 大 (большой), 田 (рисовое поле), 隹 (старая птица)
Ru_trainchinese: fèn: (графема) стараться, усердно работать; поднимать, задирать
Kanshudo_mnemonic: the big little bird (奞) in the rice field (田) is lively
chinese_mnemonics_deck__story: For one to grow a large rice field one must really exert oneself.
humanum_full_description_en:
Bronze inscriptions from " clothes " from "隹" (like bird shape) from " fields ", elephant birds take off from the fields, just like people shaking their clothes, both are called " fen " (Gao Hongjin). Shirakawa Jing thinks that he puts the caught bird in his clothes, and the bird wants to escape, so " Feng " has the meaning of flapping its wings and inspiring it. Dong Lianchi thinks that the bird is caught in his clothes and flies to the field.

In the later period, the inscriptions changed from " scratch ", from " clothes " to small seals to " big ". The form of " clothes " in the word " duo " in bronze inscriptions to small seals is also changed to " big ". See " capture ". The " clothes " in the Qin bamboo slips of the sleeping tiger land and the Han silk scripts of Mawangdui have been corrupted into " yi ".

Bronze inscription means vibrate, shake, Zhongshan Wangding: "Fen Zhen Qiao (Vibration) Duo". "Fen Yan" means "Feng Xiao", which means shaking the drumstick, that is, drumming. "Zhou Li. Land official. Xiao Zai: "Using Wooden Duo", Zheng's Note: "The ancients will have a new order, the wooden Duo will be used to police the people, so that the people will listen to it. The wooden duo, the wooden tongue. ""Guang Ya. "Explanation": "Fen, move." "Guang Yun. Question Rhyme: "Fen, Yang Ye." Also used as a name. (Refer to "General Explanation of Inscriptions in Form and Meaning")

The bamboo slips of the Warring States period express hard work and cheer, "Shangbo Chu Zhushu Five. "Three Virtues" Jane 1: "Feng Mu Xun (time) and sentence (later) Fen", which means that the vegetation waits for the right season before it can grow.

"Said Wen": "Fen, Hui Ye. Cong Xin is in the field. The Poetry says: You can't fly." Duan Yucai's note: "Tian You Ye Ye."
humanum_short_description_en: Bronze inscriptions from " clothes " from "隹" (like bird shape) from " fields ", elephant birds take off from the fields, just like people shaking their clothes, both are called " Fen " (Gao Hongjin).
humanum_full_description:
金文從「衣」從「隹」(象鳥形)從「田」，象鳥從田中起飛，如同人振衣，皆稱為「奮」(高鴻縉)。白川靜則認為將捕到的鳥放入衣內，而鳥欲逃出，因此「奮」有振翅、振奮之義。董蓮池認為以鳥被捉住懷於衣內，奮而欲飛往田野之狀來會奮意。

　　後期金文加從「攴」，所從的「衣」至小篆訛變為「大」。金文「奪」字中之「衣」形至小篆亦訛變為「大」。參見「奪」。睡虎地秦簡、馬王堆漢帛書「衣」訛變為「亦」。

　　金文表示振動，搖動，中山王鼎：「奮桴䢅(振)鐸」。「奮桴」即「奮枹」，表示搖動鼓槌，亦即擊鼓。《周禮．地官．小宰》：「徇之以木鐸」，鄭注：「古者將有新令必奮木鐸以警眾，使明聽也。木鐸，木舌也。文事奮木鐸，武事奮金鐸。」《廣雅．釋詁》：「奮，動也。」《廣韻．問韻》：「奮，揚也。」又用作人名。(參《金文形義通解》)

　　戰國竹簡表示奮發、振作，《上博楚竹書五．三德》簡1：「芔木須旹(時)而句(後)奮」，表示草木等待適合的時節而後才能奮發生長。

　　《說文》：「奮，翬也。从奞在田上。《詩》曰：不能奮飛。」段玉裁注：「田猶野也。」
humanum_short_description: 金文從「衣」從「隹」(象鳥形)從「田」，象鳥從田中起飛，如同人振衣，皆稱為「奮」(高鴻縉)。

奮奮RS
奋奋 		strive, exert effort, arouse, take wing, advance
  • RS. like a (big 大) bird spreading its wings 奞 over the field 田: rise in force and advance
  • ⓢ modf. 奮 → 奋
(Simplified: 奋)
Chinese Definition:
Ideographic: A man 大 working on the farm 田
  • ⿳ Above to middle and below
    • 大 [ dà ] big, great, vast, high, deep
    • 隹 [ zhuī ] short-tailed bird; sparrow
    • 田 [ tián ] field, farm, arable land; cultivated
①鳥張開並振動翅膀：奮飛。奮翅。
②振作，鼓勁，振動：奮起。奮力。奮勇。奮不顧身。振奮。勤奮。興奮。
③提起，舉起：奮臂。奮袂(舉袖，形容奮發的樣子)。奮筆疾書。
④用本義。［合］奮翅(振翼起飛)；奮翼(振翼高飛)；奮翔(振翼高飛)；奮鱗(龍騰飛)；奮翮(展翅，振羽)。
⑤鼓起勁來，振作。［合］奮烈(振奮威武)；奮信(振奮伸張)；奮武揚威(振奮勇氣，施展威風)；奮氣(奮發振作)。
⑥震動。［合］奮首(搖頭，表示疲睏)；奮髯(抖動鬍鬚)；奮蹄(振蹄)。
⑦奮力；施展；發揮。［合］奮張(有力地伸展、張開)；奮末(四肢用力)。
⑧揮動；舉起；舞動。［合］奮臂(有力地舉臂，表示振奮)；奮袂(舉袖，揮袖，形容振奮)；奮筆(提筆疾書)；奮戈(使勁揮舞干戈)。
奮鬥 [ fèn dòu ]: to strive; to struggle
奮戰 [ fèn zhàn ]: to fight bravely; (fig.) to struggle; to work hard

金文從「 衣 」從「 隹 」(象鳥形)從「 田 」，象鳥從田中起飛，如同人振衣，皆稱為「 奮 」(高鴻縉)。白川靜則認為將捕到的鳥放入衣內，而鳥欲逃出，因此「 奮 」有振翅、振奮之義。董蓮池認為以鳥被捉住懷於衣內，奮而欲飛往田野之狀來會奮意。 後期金文加從「 攴 」，所從的「 衣 」至小篆訛變為「 大 」。金文「 奪 」字中之「 衣 」形至小篆亦訛變為「 大 」。參見「 奪 」。睡虎地秦簡、馬王堆漢帛書「 衣 」訛變為「 亦 」。 金文表示振動，搖動，中山王鼎：「奮桴䢅(振)鐸」。「奮桴」即「奮枹」，表示搖動鼓槌，亦即擊鼓。《周禮．地官．小宰》：「徇之以木鐸」，鄭注：「古者將有新令必奮木鐸以警眾，使明聽也。木鐸，木舌也。文事奮木鐸，武事奮金鐸。」《廣雅．釋詁》：「奮，動也。」《廣韻．問韻》：「奮，揚也。」又用作人名。(參《金文形義通解》) 戰國竹簡表示奮發、振作，《上博楚竹書五．三德》簡1：「芔木須旹(時)而句(後)奮」，表示草木等待適合的時節而後才能奮發生長。 《說文》：「奮，翬也。从奞在田上。《詩》曰：不能奮飛。」段玉裁注：「田猶野也。」
Bronze inscriptions from " clothes" from " 隹" (like bird shape) from " fields", elephant birds take off from the fields, just like people shaking their clothes, both are called " fen" (Gao Hongjin). Shirakawa Jing thinks that he puts the caught bird in his clothes, and the bird wants to escape, so " Feng" has the meaning of flapping its wings and inspiring it. Dong Lianchi thinks that the bird is caught in his clothes and flies to the field. In the later period, the inscriptions changed from " scratch", from " clothes" to small seals to " big". The form of " clothes" in the word " duo" in bronze inscriptions to small seals is also changed to " big". See " capture". The " clothes" in the Qin bamboo slips of the sleeping tiger land and the Han silk scripts of Mawangdui have been corrupted into " yi". Bronze inscription means vibrate, shake, Zhongshan Wangding: "Fen Zhen Qiao (Vibration) Duo". "Fen Yan" means "Feng Xiao", which means shaking the drumstick, that is, drumming. "Zhou Li. Land official. Xiao Zai: "Using Wooden Duo", Zheng's Note: "The ancients will have a new order, the wooden Duo will be used to police the people, so that the people will listen to it. The wooden duo, the wooden tongue. ""Guang Ya. "Explanation": "Fen, move." "Guang Yun. Question Rhyme: "Fen, Yang Ye." Also used as a name. (Refer to "General Explanation of Inscriptions in Form and Meaning") The bamboo slips of the Warring States period express hard work and cheer, "Shangbo Chu Zhushu Five. "Three Virtues" Jane 1: "Feng Mu Xun (time) and sentence (later) Fen", which means that the vegetation waits for the right season before it can grow. "Said Wen": "Fen, Hui Ye. Cong Xin is in the field. The Poetry says: You can't fly." Duan Yucai's note: "Tian You Ye Ye."

奮字的基本解释

奋
（奮）
fèn ㄈㄣˋ
◎ 鸟张开并振动翅膀：～飞。～翅。
◎ 振作，鼓劲，振动：～起。～力。～勇。～不顾身。振～。勤～。兴～。
◎ 提起，举起：～臂。～袂（举袖，形容奋发的样子）。～笔疾书。

奮字的汉语字典释义

[①]［fèn］
［《廣韻》方問切，去問，非。］
“奋1”的繁体字。
(1)鸟张开翅膀。
(2)扬起；翘起。
(3)猛然用力。
(4)用力挥动或摇动。
(5)发扬；振奋。
(6)震动。
(7)愤激。
(8)骄矜，矜夸。
(9)姓。春秋时楚有司马奋扬。见《左传·昭公二十年》。

奮字的康熙字典解释

【丑集下】【大字部】　奮； 康熙笔画：16； 页码：页254第09
【廣韻】【集韻】【韻會】【正韻】?方問切，音僨。【說文】翬也。【爾雅·釋鳥】雉，絕有力奮。羊，絕有力奮。螽醜奮。鳥張羽奮奞也。【詩·邶風】不能奮飛。【史記·樂書】羽翮奮，角觡生。　又震動也。【易·豫?】雷出地奮。　又揚也。【禮·樂記】奮至德之光。　又振去塵也。【禮·曲禮】僕展軨效駕，奮衣由右上。　又姓。【左傳】楚有司馬奮揚。　又叶普麫切，音片。【孫楚·韓信贊】秦失其鹿，英雄交戰。遂寤明主，超然虎奮。　从奞在田上。俗作?，非。?字原从奞从旧。

奮字的源字形

字源演变：

金文小篆楷体

字形对比：

中国大陆宋体台湾细明体香港明体日本明朝体韩国明朝体旧字形
奮字的起名意思

暂无。

Enthusiasm
Basic explanation of words
Enthusiasm
(Feng)
fèn ㄈㄣˋ
◎ The bird opens and flaps its wings: ~ Fly. ~ Wings.
◎ Cheer up, cheer up, vibrate: ~ start. ~ Force. ~ Yong. ~ Regardless of yourself. Zhen~. Qin~. Xing~.
◎ Lift, raise: ~ arm. ~ Sleeve (raise sleeves, describe the look of striving). ~ Pen disease book.
Enthusiasm
Chinese dictionary definition of words
[①]［fèn］
["Guangyun" Fang asked Qi, to ask, no. ]
The traditional characters of "奋1".
(1) The bird spreads its wings.
(2) Raise; cock.
(3) Suddenly exert force.
(4) Vigorously wave or shake.
(5) Carry forward; inspire.
(6) Vibration.
(7) Indignation.
(8) Pride and boast.
(9) Last name. In the Spring and Autumn Period, there was Sima Fenyang in Chu. See "Zuo Zhuan·Twenty Years of Zhao Gong".

Took Zhang Yu Fen Yan also. 【Poetry·Bei Feng】Can't fly hard. [Historical Records·Book of Music] Yu Heifen, horned horns were born.　It's shaking again. Enthusiasm
Name meaning

fèn
strive, exert effort; arouse
Radicals: 大, 隹, 田  (big, turkey, rice-paddy)
Meaning Mnemonic
A big turkey in the rice paddy is getting all stirred up. He's kicking up all the rice. Who stirred him up?
He is a really big turkey too. Like, 12 feet tall, or something. Don't want to stir up a turkey that's that big.
Reading Mnemonic
While the turkey is stirred up, it also looks like it's having a lot of fun (ふん).
Is it laughing? Oh no, this is bad, it's enjoying being stirred up, now we'll never stop it.

大 (большой), 田 (рисовое поле), 隹 (старая птица)
奮うふるう
  • вызывать к жизни, разжигать, призывать на помощь (напр. мужество)
